docs.lead_paragraph: Joseph Heller, the author of ''Catch-22,'' the darkly comic 1961 novel whose title became a universal metaphor not only for the insanity of war but also for the madness of life itself, died on Sunday night at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 76. The cause was a heart attack, his wife, Valerie, said.

headline.main: Joseph Heller, Darkly Surreal Novelist, Dies at 76

docs.abstract: Joseph Heller, whose 1961 novel Catch-22 became American classic and universal metaphor for madness of life itself, dies at age 76; obituary article recalls novel, based on Heller's experiences in World War II, as well as his other work; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Repeated checks of the nation's medical equipment have uncovered no serious prospect of Year 2000 computer failures, according to federal health officials and doctors responsible for safeguarding consumers. These doctors and officials say very few medical devices need to know the year. They add that there are plenty of prescription drugs, so consumers should not hoard.

headline.main: Medical Devices Do Well in Year 2000 Tests

docs.abstract: Federal health officials and doctors responsible for safeguarding consumers report that repeated checks of nation's medical equipment have uncoverec no serious prospect of Year 2000 computer failures (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first few days of next year, hundreds of thousands of Americans are likely to discover they cannot get cash from a teller machine. Others will suddenly lose power or be greeted with silence when they pick up their telephones. There will be neighborhood pharmacies asking customers to pay in full for medicines because insurers' computers do not recognize their names. And thousands of business and home computers are likely to be penetrated by vandals or thieves.

headline.main: Year 2000 Computer Problems May Get an Alibi

docs.abstract: President';s Council on Year 2000 Conversion makes its first attempt to publicize 'normal' computer failure rates for activities in wide range of industries and government services to gain perspective on potential Year 2000 problems, and perhaps head off sensationalized coverage and panic; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the theme from ''Mission Impossible'' played in the background, Kirk Bailey and a crowd of about 150 other computer security experts waited for the results of a high-technology treasure hunt. The prize? Mr. Bailey's most personal information. Mr. Bailey, whose job includes protecting the privacy of medical records, considers himself an average citizen, though somewhat more careful about what he calls the ''fragile condition'' of privacy today. In October, Mr. Bailey dared a group of security experts to spend two months trying to dig up as much as they could about him. Their only constraints were to stay within the confines of the law and to avoid asking his family or friends for help.

headline.main: An Expert in Computer Security Finds His Life Is a Wide-Open Book

docs.abstract: Kirk Bailey, computer security expert, is discomfitted by amount of personal information about him that was gleaned by other computer security experts, who took him up on dare to dig up as much as they could about him, without breaking law; without Bailey's cooperation, permission or knowledge, researchers found scannable sample of his signature, copies of his home phone bills, learned value of his home, terms of his divorce, as well as his Social Security number and date of birth; separately, no single bit of information is particularly dangerous; but in aggregate, and in wrong hands, it could be ruinous; photo; chart (M)
docs.snippet: As the theme from ''Mission Impossible'' played in the background, Kirk Bailey and a crowd of about 150 other computer security experts waited for the results of a high-technology treasure hunt. The prize? Mr. Bailey's most personal information.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: One in every five Americans experiences a mental disorder in any given year, and half of all Americans have such disorders at some time in their lives, but most of them never seek treatment, the surgeon general of the United States says in a comprehensive new report. Many people with mental disorders do not realize that effective treatments exist, or they fear discrimination because of the stigma attached to mental illness, the study found. And, it said, many people cannot afford treatment because they lack insurance that would cover it.
docs.abstract: Surgeon general, Dr David Satcher, says that one in every five Americans experiences a mental disorder in any given year and that half of all Americans have such disorders at some time in their lives, but that most of them never seek treatment; says that many do not realize that effective treatments exist, that others fear being stigmatized and discriminated against and that still others are deterred from seeking treatment because they lack insurance that would cover it; says mental health must be part of mainstream health care, not an afterthought or an offshoot; endorses efforts by some states and members of Congress to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental disorders and other illnesses; photo (M)
docs.snippet: One in every five Americans experiences a mental disorder in any given year, and half of all Americans have such disorders at some time in their lives, but most of them never seek treatment, the surgeon general of the United States says in a...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is disappointing that Gov. George E. Pataki proposes to make health coverage affordable only to the unemployed (news article, Dec. 9). Surely Mr. Pataki doesn't want New Yorkers to give up their jobs to get health coverage when three of four of the 2.4 million uninsured adults in New York are working.

docs.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE B. LINDSEY, the former Federal Reserve governor who is now George W. Bush's chief economic adviser, sees himself as a mere technician, helping to turn the presidential candidate's vision into nuts-and-bolts programs. ''Governor Bush has a very clear idea of where he wants to take the country,'' Mr. Lindsey said the other evening, winding down after a hectic week of helping him make his first big economic policy speech of the campaign. ''We're there to provide suggestions on the best way to accomplish the policy.''

headline.main: At Bush's Ear, A Supply-Sider With a Heart

docs.abstract: Profile of Lawrence B Lindsey, former Federal Reserve governor who is now Republican presidential candidate George W Bush's chief economic adviser; focuses on Lindsey's $483 billion tax-cutting proposal that is centerpiece of Bush's economic platform; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fight over health care in Albany is threatening to delay renewal of a crucial state law that will expire on Dec. 31. The Legislature is expected to hold a special session next week, but in typical Albany fashion, the negotiations between Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders are cloaked in secrecy, and nothing may get done. If the Legislature fails to act, the expiration of the law, the Health Care Reform Act, could cause serious disruptions for the whole health care system. The law, passed in 1996, deregulated hospital rates in New York State, allowing market competition into the hospital sector. It also created new surcharges on hospital bills and on insurance companies to help finance public services, such as medical education and charity care, that would not be paid for if left to market forces. The surcharges raise about $1.8 billion a year in special funds to meet public health needs. Unless the legislators and the governor can agree on reauthorizing that law, teaching hospitals and hospitals serving the poor, as well as many public health programs, will lose hundreds of millions of dollars.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Gov George Pataki and leaders of New York State Legislature to at least extend Health Care Reform Act, which expires Dec 31, without further cutting aid to hospitals that serve the needy (M)
